results.headline: Review: In ‘Maya the Bee Movie,’ a Young Dreamer Escapes the Hive Mentality
results.summary_short: Maya hears nothing but “don’ts” from grown-ups: “Bees don’t dream” and “Bees don’t sing” and “Bees don’t have fun.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maya the Bee Movie

results.headline: Review: ‘Reality,’ an Absurdist Comedy of Dreams and Movie Nightmares
results.summary_short: The film, written and directed by Quentin Dupieux, stars Alain Chabat, Jonathan Lambert and Jon Heder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Réalité

results.headline: Review: ‘Marie’s Story,’ a Tale Similar to Helen Keller’s
results.summary_short: In this Jean-Pierre Améris film, a nun takes a deaf and blind girl under her wing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marie's Story

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ride,’ Helen Hunt Goes Surfing
results.summary_short: Directed and written by Ms. Hunt, this movie follows a high-strung New Yorker editor as she tracks down her son on the West Coast.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ride

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hyena,’ a Rogue Cop Finds Himself in Too Deep
results.summary_short: As kingpins do battle in London in Gerald Johnson’s drama, there’s plenty of human trafficking, drug smuggling and viscera.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hyena

results.headline: Review: In ‘Gerontophilia,’ a Youth Is Attracted to Old Men
results.summary_short: This Bruce LaBruce film is a sincere and tastefully observed indie romance, flavored with a sweetly droll sense of humor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gérontophilie

results.headline: Review: In ‘Far From Men,’ a Teacher Caught in the Crossfire
results.summary_short: Two starkly different men are thrown together in this film inspired by a short story by Albert Camus.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Loin Des Hommes

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cathedrals of Culture,’ Buildings to Love
results.summary_short: A two-part program of short films by directors including Wim Wenders and Robert Redford tours structures that transcend mere architectural concerns.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cathedrals of Culture

results.headline: Review: ‘Far From the Madding Crowd,’ the Rom-Com
results.summary_short: Carey Mulligan stars in Thomas Vinterberg’s adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel, with Matthias Schoenaerts, Tom Sturridge and Michael Sheen as her Victorian suitors.

results.headline: Review: ‘Cas & Dylan,’ a Road Movie Starring Richard Dreyfuss
results.summary_short: The film follows a pair of mismatched travelers heading across Canada.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cas & Dylan

results.headline: Review: ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron’ Gets the Superband Back Together
results.summary_short: The new installment in the “Avengers” franchise adds characters, including the Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver, even as its familiar heroes fight battles terrestrial and galactic.

results.headline: ‘Days of Grace,’ a Mexican Film by Everardo Gout
results.summary_short: The film uses three plotlines that take place during successive World Cups, in 2002, 2006 and 2010.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Days of Grace

results.headline: Review: In ‘Iris,’ Albert Maysles Explores Iris Apfel’s Style
results.summary_short: Mr. Maysles’s penultimate documentary shows the 93-year-old Ms. Apfel in all her bedecked glory, and the confused reactions she elicits.

results.display_title: Soul Boys of the Western World
results.headline: Review: ‘Soul Boys of the Western World’ Revisits Spandau Ballet
results.summary_short: This documentary chronicles the British band from its beginnings in 1980s London to its later dissolution.

results.headline: Review: A Young Man’s Voyage, Awash in Taboo Desires, in ‘Blackbird’
results.summary_short: The earnest, laudable and heartfelt intentions of “Blackbird” carry it far — just not far enough.

results.headline: Review: ‘Wa-shoku,’ a Documentary, Recounts How Japanese Dishes Took Hold in the U.S.
results.summary_short: Through interviews with chefs and others, the documentary “Wa-shoku: Beyond Sushi” explores the growing popularity of Japanese cuisine in American cities.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Great Museum,’ a Stroll Through the Kunsthistorisches in Vienna
results.summary_short: Johannes Holzhausen’s film subtly raises the question of how centuries-old art should be presented to a modern audience.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Forger’ Stars John Travolta as a Convict and Painter
results.summary_short: In this film, a prison inmate must fabricate a Monet as part of a shadowy deal to get out of prison early.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Age of Adaline’ Coasts Through the Decades
results.summary_short: “The Age of Adaline,” starring Blake Lively, follows the immortal Adaline, who is forever 29.

results.headline: Review: ‘Misery Loves Comedy’ Puts Stand-Up in the Spotlight
results.summary_short: Kevin Pollak’s survey of professional comics is an evident labor of love, but traffics more in abstraction than in revelations about the creative process.
